p.text: Evidence of an opinion is not admissible to prove the existence of a fact about the existence of which the opinion was expressed.

Subsection (1) does not apply to evidence of an opinion contained in a certificate or other document given or made under regulations made under an Act other than this Act to the extent to which the regulations provide that the certificate or other document has evidentiary effect.
[subs (2) insrt Act No 53 of 2000 Sch 1]
Specific exceptions to the opinion rule are as follows:
character of and expert opinion about accused persons ( sections 110 and 111 ).
Other provisions of this Act, or of other laws, may operate as further exceptions.

P sues D, her doctor, for the negligent performance of a surgical operation. Unless an exception to the opinion rule applies, P's neighbour, W, who had the same operation, cannot give evidence of his opinion that D had not performed the operation as well as his own.

P considers that electrical work that D, an electrician, has done for her is unsatisfactory. Unless an exception to the opinion rule applies, P cannot give evidence of her opinion that D does not have the necessary skills to do electrical work.
[s 76 am Act No 46 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 1[32], effective 1 January 2009]
ALRC 26 vol 1 paras 348–351, 738
ALRC 38 para 148
This section is defined in the Dictionary as the “opinion rule” for the purposes of the Act.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [50,690] s 77 Exception: evidence relevant otherwise than as opinion evidence

leg:heading.title: Exception: evidence relevant otherwise than as opinion evidence

p.text: The opinion rule does not apply to evidence of an opinion that is admitted because it is relevant for a purpose other than proof of the existence of a fact about the existence of which the opinion was expressed.
ALRC 38 para 148
Legislation cited in [50,690.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 136.

The section contemplates that evidence may be admissible for a limited purpose notwithstanding the opinion rule. By stipulating that the opinion rule does not apply to evidence so admitted, the section permits the evidence to be used to establish the facts in question. The effect of the section is to allow admitted evidence to be used for purposes other than for which it was originally admissible. In connection with the operation of the section it will be necessary to consider the discretion conferred by s 136 to limit the use to which the evidence can be put: see generally the note in [29.2.25] .
The opinion rule does not apply to evidence of an opinion expressed by a person if:
the opinion is based on what the person saw, heard or otherwise perceived about a matter or event, and
evidence of the opinion is necessary to obtain an adequate account or understanding of the person's perception of the matter or event.
ALRC 26 vol 1 paras 739–740
ALRC 38 para 148

The distinction between fact and opinion is sometimes difficult to draw — and sometimes a matter of semantics. Recognising this, the common law allowed various non-expert opinions to be admitted, a principle which is now embodied in the provisions of s 78 of the Act. Typically the kinds of situations where non expert opinions are admissible are those where they are essential to an adequate communication of the extent and significance of the witness's observations: J D Heydon, Cross on Evidence, LexisNexis, vol 1, at [29,130]; R v Kelly [1958] VR 412 . Examples of these kinds of opinion evidence include:
evidence of identification: Lucas v Williams & Sons [1982] 2 QB 113; Fryer v Gathercole (1849) 13 Jur 542;

evidence about speed, weather, handwriting and age: R v Cox [1898] 1 QB 179; (1897) 18 Cox CC 672; [1895] All ER Rep 1285 ; R v Whitby (1957) 74 WN (NSW) 441 ; Wise v Musolino [1936] SASR 447 ; Voros v Janosne [2000] NSWSC 1166; BC200007574
lay evidence about a person’s sobriety and apparent consumption of alcohol: R v Davies [1962] 3 All ER 97 .

Even outside these areas (where the “opinion” could be characterised as no more than a compendious way of stating the effect of a number of related factual observations) non-expert opinion evidence could be admissible. For example, a witness could give an opinion about value in situations where no specialised knowledge was required: R v Beckett (1913) 8 Cr App R 204. Furthermore, a witness could answer hypothetical questions related to issues of reliance: Mansell v Clements (1874) LR9CP 139 . The present section confirms the admissibility of non-expert opinions in relation to these types of matters. However, there must obviously be some independent rational basis for the admission of the lay opinion: Idoport Pty Ltd v National Australia Bank Ltd [2001] NSWSC 670; BC200104560 .

The weight of authority favours the proposition that the section has a relatively narrow operation and assumes that the matter or event perceived by the witness is the primary evidence and that the opinion is admissible as being incidental to an understanding of the primary evidence: see R v Leung (1999) 47 NSWLR 405; [1999] NSWCCA 287; BC9905924 per Simpson J; Australian Securities and Investments Commission v Vines [2003] NSWSC 1237; BC200307987 per Austin J; cf Connex Group Australia Pty Ltd v Butt [2004] NSWSC 379; BC200402627 . The mere fact that the perception of the witness might be consistent with other relevant physical evidence will not, of itself, make evidence of the perception admissible under the section: R v Panetta (1997) 26 MVR 332; BC9704859 . Similarly, non-expert opinion evidence is inadmissible if it goes beyond the interpretative description of the witness’ perceptions of events and opines as to the apparent cause of those events: Lithgow City Council v Jackson (2011) 244 CLR 352; 281 ALR 223; [2011] HCA 36; BC201107453 (ambulance officers notes — opinion as to circumstances of victim’s injuries — inadmissible opinion).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [50,697] s 78A Exception: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander traditional laws and customs

leg:heading.title: Exception: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander traditional laws and customs

p.text: The opinion rule does not apply to evidence of an opinion expressed by a member of an Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander group about the existence or non-existence, or the content, of the traditional laws and customs of the group.
[s 78A insrt Act No 46 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 1[33], effective 1 January 2009]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [50,700] s 79 Exception: opinions based on specialised knowledge

leg:heading.title: Exception: opinions based on specialised knowledge

p.text: If a person has specialised knowledge based on the person's training, study or experience, the opinion rule does not apply to evidence of an opinion of that person that is wholly or substantially based on that knowledge.
To avoid doubt, and without limiting subsection (1) :

a reference in that subsection to specialised knowledge includes a reference to specialised knowledge of child development and child behaviour (including specialised knowledge of the impact of sexual abuse on children and their development and behaviour during and following the abuse), and

a reference in that subsection to an opinion of a person includes, if the person has specialised knowledge of the kind referred to in paragraph (a) , a reference to an opinion relating to either or both of the following:
the development and behaviour of children generally,
the development and behaviour of children who have been victims of sexual offences, or offences similar to sexual offences.
[subs (2) insrt Act No 46 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 1[34], effective 1 January 2009]
ALRC 38 para 148, 149
Legislation cited in [50,700.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rr 31.17–31.45, rr 31.46–31.54.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 79.

Ordinarily, the expert evidence must explain how their field of specialised knowledge training study or experience, applies to the facts assumed or observed and gives rise to the opinion propounded: Dasreef Pty Ltd v Hawchar (2011) 277 ALR 611; 85 ALJR 694; [2011] HCA 21; BC201104304 citing Makita (Aust) Pty Ltd v Sprowles (2001) 52 NSWLR 705 at 744; 25 NSWCCR 218; [2001] NSWCA 305; BC200105538 .
UCPR rr 31.17–31.45 contain provisions in relation to experts called by parties. UCPR rr 31.46–31.54 provide that experts may be appointed by the court.

At common law expert opinion evidence was not admissible unless it related to a recognised field of expertise. But there was considerable scope to debate what constituted a recognised field of expertise. On one view, the claimed area of expertise had to be “sufficiently established to have gained general acceptance in the particular field to which it belongs”: R v Gilmore [1977] 2 NSWLR 935; R v Runjanjic (1991) 56 SASR 114 at 119; 53 A Crim R 362 ; R v Lucas [1992] 2 VR 109 at 115; R v Lewis (1987) 29 A Crim R 267 at 269; R v Bonython (1984) 38 SASR 45 at 46–7 . On another view, it was sufficient if the court was satisfied that there was a reliable basis for the opinion: Clark v Ryan (1960) 103 CLR 486; [1960] ALR 524 ; Casley Smith v Evans & Sons Pty Ltd (No 1) (1988) 49 SASR 314 at 320, 328 . In neither case was the evidence necessarily inadmissible merely because the opinion was based upon a particular unproven theory that was not supported by the weight of scientific opinion: Commissioner for Govt Transport v Adamcik (1961) 106 CLR 292 at 306; [1961] ALR 892 .

The requirement in s 79 is simply that the opinion be based upon an area of “specialised knowledge”. This requirement is apparently more liberal than the previous common law position and has been held sufficiently wide to encompass the concept of an “ad hoc” expert: Butera v DPP (Vic) (1987) 164 CLR 180; 76 ALR 45; BC8701825 ; R v Leung (1999) 47 NSWLR 405; [1999] NSWCCA 287; BC9905924 (interpreter familiar with a particular person’s voice); R v Cassar [1999] NSWSC 436; BC9902633 ; R v Drollett [2005] NSWCCA 356; BC200509470 at [63] . But there is still room for controversy about what falls within that expression: see Daubert v Merrell Dow Pharmaceuticals (1993) 61 USLW 4805 at 4808 cited in Odgers, Uniform Evidence Law, at p 127. What degree of experience or skill is required by the concept of “specialised knowledge” must depend upon the circumstances of the particular case. If the matter is one of technical, scientific expertise it is difficult to see that appropriate expertise could be acquired without extensive formal education.
On the other hand, specialised knowledge may be shown merely as a consequence of relevant experience. This has resulted in opinion evidence being admitted on a wide range of topics — including:
Adolescent behaviour:
Transport Publishing Co Ltd v Literature Board of Review (1956) 99 CLR 111; [1958] ALR 177; [1957] St R Qd 19; BC5600780 ;
Community attitudes:
Yildiz v R (1983) 11 A Crim R 115 (community attitudes);
Ergonomics:
Nair-Smith v Perisher Blue Pty Ltd [2012] NSWSC 1070; BC201206942 ;
Investor behaviour:
Allstate Life Insurance Co v ANZ Banking Group Ltd (No 6) (1996) 64 FCR 79 at 85; 137 ALR 138; BC9601160 ;
Marketing:
Sydneywide Distributors Pty Ltd v Red Bull Australia Pty Ltd (2002) 55 IPR 354; [2002] FCAFC 157; BC200202932 at [7];
Physical education and weight management:
Australian Competition & Consumer Commission v Emerald Ocean Distributors Pty Ltd [2002] FCA 740; BC200204219 at [13] (physical education and weight management programmes);
Prison escapees:
Godfrey v New South Wales (No 1) (2003) 25 NSWCCR 291; [2003] NSWSC 160; BC200300892 ;
Sporting ability and potential earnings:
Jermen v Shell Co of Australia Ltd [2003] NSWSC 1106; BC200307299 ;
Store security:
Voice and visual identification:

R v Leung (1999) 47 NSWLR 405; [1999] NSWCCA 287; BC9905924 (interpreter familiar with a particular person's voice); R v Marsh [2005] NSWCCA 331; BC200507555 (close relative familiar with person's appearance);
Video and voice recordings:
R v Clare [1995] 2 Cr App R 333 (numerous viewings of a video film); R v Menzies [1982] 1 NZLR 40 (repeated playing of taping recording).

level.toc-caption: [50,700.15] Wholly or substantially based on that knowledge

p.text: Legislation cited in [50,700.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 135, 136.

heading.title: Wholly or substantially based on that knowledge

p.text: The expert opinion is only admissible to the extent that it is based on the specialised knowledge: HG v R (1999) 197 CLR 414; 160 ALR 554; [1999] HCA 2; BC9900188 ; Pownall v Conlan Management Pty Ltd (1995) 12 WAR 370 at 375–7; 16 ACSR 227 . This requirement is logically fundamental to the admissibility of the expert opinion under the present section: Ocean Marine Mutual Insurance Association (Europe) OV v Jetopay Pty Ltd (2000) 120 FCR 146; [2000] FCA 1463; BC200007242 .

The requirement means that ordinarily, the expert’s evidence must explain how the expert’s professed field of “specialised knowledge” applies to the facts assumed or observed so as to produce the basis for the opinion propounded: Dasreef Pty Ltd v Hawchar (2011) 243 CLR 588; 277 ALR 611; [2011] HCA 21; BC201104304 ; Cooper v R [2011] NSWCCA 258; BC 201109697 . It is a requirement that may have particular significance when the expert opinion is based upon a selective discrimination between, or evaluation of, assumed or primary facts: Bone v Wallalong Investments [2012] NSWSC 137; BC201200985 (expert valuer’s report — report failed to explain the reasoning process used to discriminate between "comparable" sales — report failed to state reasons for selecting a particular discount rate — inadmissible); Arcus ShopFitters Pty Ltd v Western Australian Planning Commission (2002) 125 LGERA 180; [2002] WASC 174; BC200203570 at [78].

On the other hand, practical considerations related to the efficient and expeditious conduct of proceedings, may mean that the admissibility of an expert’s report is likely to be determined as a matter impression derived from the apparent sufficiency of the expert’s reasoning. What might be required, in any particular case, will depend upon the particular circumstances: Sydneywide Distributors Pty Ltd v Red Bull Australia Pty Ltd (2002) 55 IPR 354; [2002] FCAFC 157; BC200202932 ; Adler v ASIC (2003) 179 FLR 1; 46 ACSR 504; [2003] NSWCA 131; BC200303670 ; Paino v Paino (2008) 40 Fam LR 96; [2008] NSWCA 276; BC200809573 at [59]ff . See also [31.29.25] .

Where the opinion is based on specialised knowledge applied to particular facts, it is potentially important to clarify whether those facts are matters of assumption, specialised knowledge, or have some other potentially inadmissible source: Makita (Aust) Pty Ltd v Sprowles (2001) 52 NSWLR 705; BC200105538; [2001] NSWCA 305 . The ultimate accuracy of those matters is not a pre-condition to the admissibility of the report: Australian Securities and Investments Commission v Rich (2005) 218 ALR 764; 54 ACSR 326; [2005] NSWCA 152; BC200503400 at [132]–[136], [163], [168], [170] . But a clear statement of the matters relied on may demonstrate either that the opinion is not based substantially on the specialised knowledge and is, therefore, either inadmissible (HG v R (1999) 197 CLR 414; 160 ALR 554; [1999] HCA 2; BC9900188 ); or liable to be excluded as misleading or unfairly prejudicial under s 135 of the Evidence Act: Australian Securities and Investments Commission v Rich [2005] NSWSC 650; BC200504865 at [5] . The opinion will be inadmissible if it is wholly based on assumptions and the material matters are not the subject of admissible evidence: Dasreef Pty Ltd v Hawchar, above at [90].

Thus, an accountant's opinion about solvency will not be admissible if it is merely an obvious inference from the books of account. Such an opinion is not based on training, study, or experience: Quick v Stoland Pty Ltd (1998) 87 FCR 371 at 379; 157 ALR 615 at 622; BC9804969 ; see also Dean-Willcocks v Commonwealth Bank of Australia (2003) 45 ACSR 564; 21 ACLC 1206; BC200302778; [2003] NSWSC 466 (inadmissible opinion about the existence of grounds to suspect insolvency); (contrast Ancher, Mortlock, Murray & Woolley Pty Ltd v Hooker Homes Pty Ltd [1971] 2 NSWLR 278; (1971) 20 FLR 481 (evidence permitted about the similarity of architectural plans). If an expert's report contains intertwined provisions, some of which are admissible and others not, the report will either be wholly inadmissible or at least invite the exclusionary discretions in ss 135 and 136 : Trust Co of Australia Ltd v Perpetual Trustees (WA) Ltd (SC(NSW), McLelland CJ, No 5723/92, 18 September 1996, unreported, BC9604322).

At common law expert evidence about the issues relevant to assessment of the reliability of identification evidence was inadmissible: Smith v R (1990) 64 ALJR 588 at 588F . Similarly, a witness’ evidence of identification involving the interpretation of photographs will ordinarily be inadmissible: R v Smith (2001) 206 CLR 650; 181 ALR 354; [2001] HCA 50; BC200104729 ; R v Drollett [2005] NSWCCA 356; BC200509470 ; unless the interpretation is provided by a witness who is able to give direct evidence of the matters depicted in the photographs: R v Drollett [2005] NSWCCA 356; BC200509470 at [55] ; or who has specialised knowledge (derived for example from familiarity with the particular person or place) , not available to the tribunal of fact, that justifies a relevant interpretation of the information depicted in the photograph: R v Marsh [2005] NSWCCA 331; BC200507555 (close relative’s identification from photograph). See also R v Leung (1999) 47 NSWLR 405; [1999] NSWCCA 287; BC9905924 .
Legislation cited in [50,700.25] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 56.

Under the common law, opinion evidence was not admissible unless its factual basis was established: Arnotts Ltd v Trade Practices Commission (1990) 24 FCR 313 at 348; 97 ALR 555 ; Bugg v Day (1949) 79 CLR 442 at 462; 23 ALJR 508; BC4900470 . There is no similar requirement under the present Act. However, the general requirement of relevance in s 56 applies. It is arguable that, unless the basis of an expert opinion is established, the requirement of relevance cannot be satisfied.

level.toc-caption: [50,700.30] Status of facts stated in an expert's report

heading.title: Status of facts stated in an expert's report

p.text: Facts stated in an expert's report should not be regarded as probative of their truth if their purpose is merely to record the assumptions on which the opinions expressed in the report were based: Quick v Stoland Pty Ltd (1998) 87 FCR 371; 157 ALR 615; BC9804969 ; Eastman v R (1997) 76 FCR 9 at 78–9; 158 ALR 107; BC9702666 . Those assumed or accepted facts should be clearly stated and, to the extent they are relevant and material to the opinion expressed, must ultimately be proved by other admissible evidence: see Makita (Australia) Pty Ltd v Sprowles (2001) 52 NSWLR 705; 25 NSWCCR 218; [2001] NSWCA 305; BC200105538 at [85] ; see also Bugg v Day (1949) 79 CLR 442 at 462; 23 ALJR 508 ; Rhoden v Wingate (2002) 36 MVR 499; [2002] NSWCA 165; BC200203353 . It is also essential for the expert to differentiate between the assumed facts upon which the opinion is based, and the opinion itself: Hancock v East Coast Timber Products Pty Ltd (2011) 8 DDCR 399; [2011] NSWCA 11; BC201100628 . Although proof of assumed or accepted facts is not, of itself, a pre-condition to the admissibility of the expert’s opinion: Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) v Rich (2005) 218 ALR 764 at [136]; 54 ACSR 326; [2005] NSWCA 152; BC200503400 and see [31.29.10] the opinion may, in the circumstances, have little or no value if part of the basis of it is not before the court: Ramsay v Watson (1961) 108 CLR 642; [1963] ALR 134; (1961) 35 ALJR 301; BC6100530 . A report may be rejected where the opinion is not sufficiently based on the stated matters: Australian Securities and Investments Commission v Rich [2005] NSWSC 650; BC200504865 at [36]–[45] ; or where it is substantially based on a factual matter the court is satisfied is unlikely to be established: Biseja Pty Ltd v NSI Group Pty Ltd [2006] NSWSC 1496; BC200611427 .

If there is a divergence between the matters assumed and those established by evidence, the materiality of the nature and extent of the divergence, to the reliability of the opinion, should be the subject of evidence: Nominal Defendant v Saleh (2011) 57 MVR 412; [2011] NSWCA 16; BC201102212 at [263] and the authorities cited therein, especially Paric v John Holland (Constructions) Pty Ltd (1985) 62 ALR 85; 59 ALJR 844; [1985] HCA 58; BC8501076 at [9] .
Legislation cited in [50,700.35] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 ss 135–137.

Even if opinion evidence is admissible under the present section, it may still be excluded in the exercise of the powers conferred by ss 135–137 . In the exercise of that discretion relevant factors will include the nature of the specialised knowledge, the nature of the opinion, the nature of the issue to which it relates, the effect of its admission upon the conduct of the proceedings and whether there is a risk that its admission will shift the focus of the proceedings “from the evidence of the facts in dispute to the conflict between... competing theories”: Murphy v R (1989) 167 CLR 94 at 130–1; 86 ALR 35 .

The words “reasonably open to find” as they appear in the section make it clear that the court does not have to make a concluded finding. The court merely has to be satisfied there is a reasonable basis on which such a finding could ultimately be made. The matter to be determined on the balance of probabilities is the existence of the reasonable basis, not the existence of the ultimate conclusion as to the authority, scope of employment or furtherance of a common purpose: see Director of Public Prosecutions v Brownlee [1999] NSWCCA 57; BC9901309 , cited in Tim Barr Pty Ltd v Narui Gold Coast Pty Ltd [2008] NSWSC 1247; BC200810320 at [11] .

level.toc-caption: [50,700.45] Evidence of experts who have an interest in the outcome of the proceedings

heading.title: Evidence of experts who have an interest in the outcome of the proceedings

p.text: The evidence of an expert is not inadmissible merely because they have a material interest in the proceedings: Sydney South West Area Health Service v Stamoulis [2009] NSWCA 153; BC200906518 , esp at [213]–[219] (expert evidence given by two doctors involved in alleged negligent diagnosis); MM Constructions (Aust) Pty Ltd v Port Stephens Council (No 3) [2010] NSWSC 243; BC201001791 (town planner had advised and assisted plaintiffs in claim for damages, objection to lack of objectivity of planner in giving expert evidence rejected); Tyneside Property Management Pty Ltd v Hammersmith Management Pty Ltd [2011] NSWSC 395; BC201103990 (non-compliance with expert witness code due to association with the defendants does not impact on admissibility as expert opinion).

level.toc-caption: [50,700.50] Code of Conduct for Expert Witnesses

heading.title: Code of Conduct for Expert Witnesses

p.text: The Code of Conduct for Expert Witnesses is set out in Sch 7 of the Uniform Civil Procedure Rules. As to the consequences of non compliance with the provisions of that Code see the notes at [31.23.10].

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [50,705] s 80 Ultimate issue and common knowledge rules abolished

leg:heading.title: Ultimate issue and common knowledge rules abolished

p.text: Evidence of an opinion is not inadmissible only because it is about:
a fact in issue or an ultimate issue, or
a matter of common knowledge.
ALRC 26 Vol 1 paras 354, 359, 743
ALRC 38 para 148
Legislation cited in [50,705.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 144, Section 190.

The general position before the present section was that expert evidence could not be given of matters that were common knowledge: Clark v Ryan (1960) 103 CLR 486 at 491; [1960] ALR 524; BC6000390 ; E v Australian Red Cross Society (1991) 31 FCR 299; 105 ALR 53 ; R v Runjanjic (1991) 56 SASR 114; 53 A Crim R 362 at 369 . The kinds of matters that fall within “common knowledge” defy precise classification: R v Bonython (1984) 38 SASR 45 at 46–7 . The provision of s 80(b) removes the criterion of “common knowledge” as a separate basis for the exclusion of opinion evidence. Section 144 provides a basis for the admission of evidence of this kind. Section 190 could provide an additional basis for the reception of such evidence.

Further, s 80(a) has the effect of reversing those authorities which established that an expert witness could not be asked a question which the court itself was called upon to decide: see Grey v Australian Motorists and General Insurance Co Ltd [1976] 1 NSWLR 669 at 675 ; R v Palmer [1981] 1 NSWLR 209 at 214; (1981) 1 A Crim R 458 .

However, whilst the evidence of an expert in respect of a central issue in the proceedings is now admissible, this does not eliminate the necessity for a proper judicial assessment of the weight and reliability of the evidence: Grynberg v Muller [2001] NSWSC 532; BC200103429 . This is particularly the case where there is a risk that the opinion evidence may fall outside an area of real and relevant expertise, or express views not adequately by disclosed and contestable reasoning or assumptions: R v GK (2001) 53 NSWLR 317; 125 A Crim R 315; [2001] NSWCCA 413; BC200106763 ; Faucett v St George Bank Ltd (2003) Aust Torts Reports ¶81-699; [2003] NSWCA 43; BC200301689 .
Legislation cited in [50,705.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 79, s 80(a).

At common law a witness could not be asked to express an opinion on a matter that was the ultimate issue to be determined in the proceedings: see, for example, Grey v Australian Motorists and General Insurance Co [1976] 1 NSWLR 669 at 675–6. But the simplicity of this proposition was bedevilled by uncertainty in its application: R v Holmes [1953] 2 All ER 324; [1953] 1 WLR 686 and Yorke v Yorkshire Insurance Co Ltd [1918] 1 KB 662. The true basis of the ultimate issue principle was said to be the inadmissibility of opinion evidence involving the application of a legal standard: Palmer v R [1981] 1 NSWLR 209 at 214; (1981) 1 A Crim R 458. In any event, the present section abolishes the ultimate issue criterion as a basis for the exclusion of opinion evidence: Idoport Pty Ltd v National Australia Bank Ltd (2000) 50 NSWLR 640; [2000] NSWSC 1077; BC200007123 .

Nevertheless, evidence that touches on the ultimate issue may be inadmissible because of a lack of satisfaction that it is truly opinion evidence that satisfies the requirements of s 79 of the Evidence Act. Evidence of that kind may also be rejected because it trespasses upon the judicial function to such an extent as to justify its exclusion in the particular case: Allstate Life Insurance Co v ANZ Banking Group Ltd (No 6) (1996) 64 FCR 79 at 85; 137 ALR 138; BC9601160 ; O'Brien v Gillespie (1997) 41 NSWLR 549 ; Bostik Australia Pty Ltd v Liddiard [2009] NSWCA 167; BC200905523 . These possibilities emphasise the importance of careful scrutiny in the application of s 80(a) , lest the opinion giver asserts an expertise outside their field, or expresses views that are not supported by disclosed and contestable assumptions: R v GK (2001) 53 NSWLR 317; 125 A Crim R 315; [2001] NSWCCA 413; BC200106763 ; Roads and Traffic Authority of New South Wales v Barrie Toepfer Earthmoving & Land Management Pty Ltd [2012] NSWSC 916; BC201206371 .
